texts.en: Hakimjon is married and lives with his parents. He supports his family by running his own business of selling men’s shoes. His wife also would like to help him sell shoes. He needs to expand his business to increase his output. By doing so, he would like to borrow money with the help of a loan to increase his goods.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Taleb

texts.en: Taleb is a 58 year old man. He lives in small village near Saida in southern Lebanon. He owns a small shop where he sells candies. Taleb wants to expand and diversify his business. Therefore, he has asked for a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua. His previous six loans have always been paid on time.

loans.use: To expand and diversify his business.

loans.name: Tojiniso

texts.ru:
Муминова Тожинисо, 1974 года рождения и у нее 3 иждивенцев. Она начала свой бизнес с продажи токи. Сейчас ее ассортимент товаров увеличился, это разновидность токи (национальные головные уборы), махси (национальные сапоги) и чапаны (национальное пальто). Свой товар она закупает у поставщиков из Коканда, Андижана и продает на рынке Сафар Гисарского района.
Для увеличения товарооборота хочет получить займ в сумме 3500 сомони для закупа чапанов.
texts.en:
Tojiniso M. was born in 1974. She has 3 dependents. Tojiniso started her business by selling tokis (ethnic hats). Today, her product assortment has increased and she sells tokis (ethnic hats), mahsis (ethnic boots), and chapans (ethnic coats). She purchases her products from suppliers from Kokanda and Andizhana and sells them at the Safar market in the Gissar region. In order to increase her inventory and purchase additional coats, Tojiniso would like to take out a loan for 3500 somoni ($1050).

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase coats

loans.name: Salim

texts.en: Salim is a 52 year old man. He lives in a small village near Saida in southern Lebanon with his wife and their child. He sells fruits and vegetables and wants to increase his capitA. in the market. He has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from A. Majmoua. Salim has been a micro-credit client for 6 years and has always paid on time.

loans.use: To increase his capital by selling more fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Amina's Group

texts.en:
Amina H. has owned a restaurant in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She works from 6:00am to 3:00pm every day and earns a profit of approximately $920 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food for her restaurant to please her customers and increase her profit.

Amina is 38 years old, married, and has five children, aged 8, 12, 14, 16, and 22. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Magret, Anna, Amina, MwanaJ., and Maryam. Each has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more food for her restaurant.

loans.name: Nogaye

texts.fr: Nogaye G., 54 ans est mariée et mère de 06 enfants avec 1 autre à sa charge. Elle est membre du banc villageois de Pire Gourèye depuis 3 ans. Son activité consiste à acheter et revendre des  légumes dans le marché. Elle veut acheter des pommes de terre  et des oignons pour renforcer son commerce. <b> Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b>
texts.en:
Nogaye G., age 54, is married and the mother of six children plus one other in her care. She has been a member of the village loan group Pire Gourèye for three years. Her work involves buying and selling vegetables in the marketplace. She wants to buy potatoes and onions to bolster her commerce. The loan she is requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell vegetables

loans.name: Amina's Group

texts.en:
Amina H. has been selling clothes in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for five years. She earns a profit of approximately $25 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more inventory for her shop and increase her sales and profit. If this loan helps her to expand her business, she intends to use the increased profits to pay her children's school fees and improve her home.

Amina is 25 years old, divorced, and has two children, aged 3 and 5. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Aziza, Siti, Hadia and Mwajuma. Each has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Mahfirat

texts.ru:
Кучарова Махфират, 1984 года рождения. Зухра торгует на центральном рынке Гисара галошами и тапочками. Кроме этого дома в месте с братом занимаются откормом крупно-рогатого скота. В этом бизнесе у нее 4 года опыта. Она купила корову, чтоб откормить ее и продать по выгодной цене. Если корова будет продана за хорошую сумму, Махфират хочет купить два теленка и тоже откормить для продажи. Для покупки еще одного теленка ей нужны дополнительные средства.
Махфират хочет получить займ в сумме 4000 сомони чтоб купить корову.
texts.en:
Mahfirat K. was born in 1984. She sells galoshes (overshoes) and slippers at the central market in Gissar. In addition, she raises livestock at home with her brother. She has 4 years of experience in this business. Mahfirat bought a cow in order to fatten it and to resell it at a profit. If she can sell the cow at a good price, Mahfirat would like to buy two calves and to fatten them for sale. In order to purchase one more calf she needs additional resources. Mahfirat would like to take out a loan for 4000 somoni ($1200) in order to purchase a cow.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a calf

loans.name: Arame

texts.fr: Arame N., 51 ans, mariée avec 09 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Pire Gourèye depuis 7 ans. Elle  s’active dans l’embouche bovine. Elle veut acheter une vache  et des aliments de bétail pour renforcer son activité et améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. <b> Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Arame N., 51, married and raising 9 children, has been a member of the village bank of Pire Gourèye for 7 years. She raises cattle. She wants to buy a cow and cattle feed to boost her business and improve the living conditions of her family. The loan that she is requesting will be reimbursed at the end of 6 months in one single repayment.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of a cow and cattle feed

loans.name: Asha's Group

texts.en:
Asha M. has been selling spices, firewood and fish in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for six years. Zanzibar has a large market for spices as they grow all over the island. Asha works for twelve hours every day and earns a profit of approximately $125 each month. She has previously taken out one loan from BRAC Tanzania which she repaid successfully and on time. She is requesting her second loan so that she can buy more inventory for her shop and increase her sales and profit. If this loan helps her to expand her business, she intends to use the increased profits to pay her children's school fees and buy more food for her family.

Asha is 40 years old, married, and has six children, aged 2, 5, 16, 18, 20 and 22. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Miza and Fambo. Each has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more spices, firewood, and fish to sell.

loans.name: Hatutaki Chuki Group

texts.en:
Sikudhan S. has been selling clothes in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for six months. She earns a profit of approximately $25 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more inventory for her shop and increase her sales and profit. If this loan helps her to expand her business, she intends to use the increased profits to improve her home.

Sikudhan is 24 years old, single, and has no children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Veronica, Salma, Mvua, and Maryam. Each has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell in her business.

loans.name: Mame Yacine

texts.fr: Mame Yacine D., 50 ans est mariée et mère de 05 enfants avec 3 autres à sa charge. Elle est membre du banc villageois de Pire Gourèye depuis 7 ans. Elle achète du tissu (bazin) pour faire des draps de lit à vendre. Elle vend aussi des jus de fruit qu’elle prépare à base de pain de singe, de bissap et de sucre. Elle veut renforcer son commerce. <b> Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b>
texts.en:
Mame Yacine D., 50, is married and the mother of 5 children with 3 others for whom she is responsible. She has been a member of the village bank of Pire Gourèye for 7 years. She buys lengths of cloth ("bazin," a form of damask) to make sheets for sale. She also sells fruit juice that she prepares with monkey bread (the fruit of the baobab tree,) hibiscus flowers, and sugar. She wants to bolster her businesses.

The loan that she is requesting will be reimbursed at the end of 6 months in one single repayment.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of sheets and fruit juice

loans.name: Mamlakat

texts.ru:
Диндорова Мамлакат 1973 года рождения, она замужем и у нее один ребенок. Свою предпринимательскую деятельность она  начала в 2005 году, с продажи женской одежды.  Она торгует на центральном рынке Гисара. Так как она сама женщина и разбирается очень хорошо в тканях ей легко. У нее много клиентов, как обычные покупатели, так и швейные цеха. В его ассортименте имеются  такие ткани как  шифон, шелк, штапель  и т.д.
Свой товар Мамлакат закупает в оптовых рынках. В момент осеннего сезона ей необходимы дополнительные средства для увеличения ассортимента и количество продаваемого товара. Для этого она хочет получить займ в сумме 3600 сомони.
texts.en:
Mamlakat D. was born in 1973, is married, and has one child. She began her business in 2005 when she started selling women’s clothes. She trades in the central market in Gisara. She is a woman, and understanding different fabrics comes easily to her. She has many customers, both from the general public as well as from professional sewing shops. Her inventory includes chiffon, silk, rayon, etc.

Mamlakat buys her goods in the wholesale market. This autumn, she needs money in order to increase the assortment and quantity of the goods she sells. To do this, she wants to take out a loan for 3,600 somoni.


Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying seasonal fabric

loans.name: Mwatima's Group

texts.en:
Mwatima S. sells charcoal and firewood in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar. She works from 8:00am to 8:00pm every day and earns a profit of approximately $80 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more inventory for her shop and increase her sales and profit.

Mwatima is 42 years old, married, and has six children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Mtumwa and Time. Each has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business

loans.name: Darwish

texts.en: D. is a 45-year-old man who lives in a small village near Saida in southern Lebanon with his wife and their 2 children. He owns a small shop for changing car oil. He wants to diversify his products to answer all his clients' needs. He requested a loan of 1200 US dollars from Al Majmoua and this is the seventh loan for D. in a micro-credit field.

loans.use: He wants to diversify his business

loans.name: Mwanakombo's Group

texts.en:
For three years, Mwanakombo O. has been selling fish and charcoal in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar. She works from 7:30am to 4:00pm every day and earns a profit of approximately $250 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more inventory for her shop and increase her sales and profit.

45-year-old Mwanakombo is a single mother with one 25-year-old child. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Sarah, Rose, and Beatrice. Each has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more fish and charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
Mary B. has been renting out a Play Station video game console in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She allows people to pay to play the games from 9:00am to 3:00pm every day and earns a profit of approximately $340 each month. She has previously taken out one loan from BRAC Tanzania which she repaid successfully and on time. She is requesting her second loan so that she can buy an additional game for the Play Station game console.

Mary is 36 years old, married, and has one 12-year-old child. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Rukia, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy a new game for the Play Station game console that she rents to customers.

loans.name: Mashrab

texts.ru:
Хайиткулова Машраб 1967 года рождения, она замужем и у них 4 детей. Свою предпринимательскую деятельность она  начала в 1998 году, с продажи тканей.  Она торгует на рынке Стадион города Турсунзаде. Машраб хорошо разбирается в тканях, при покупке ее товаров она рекомендует своим клиентам при выборе. У нее много клиентов, как обычные покупатели, так и швейные цеха. В его ассортименте имеются  такие ткани как  шифон, шелк, штапель  и т.д.
Свой товар Машраб закупает в оптовом рынке Корвон. В момент осеннего сезона ей необходимы дополнительные средства для покупки осенних тканей. Для этого она хочет получить займ в сумме 4000 сомони.
texts.en:
Mashrab H. was born in 1967, is married, and has four children. She began her business in 1998 selling fabrics. She sells in the Stadium market in Tursun-Zade. Mashrab know fabrics well, and she makes recommendations to her customers. She has many customers, both from the general public as well as from professional sewing shops. Her inventory includes chiffon, silk, rayon, etc. Mashrab buys her goods in the wholesale market Korvon. It is now autumn, and she needs additional funds to purchase seasonal fabrics. Because of this, she would like to take out a loan for 4,000 somoni.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying seasonal fabric

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a 35 year old man. He lives in a small village near Saida in southern Lebanon with his parents and works as a fisherman. Ibrahim uses a unique system for catching his fish; every day he dives beneath the waters of the Mediterranean Sea to set a small metal cage with bait inside. Each afternoon, Ibrahim returns to reclaim his cage, hopefully full of fish. Ibrahim has asked for a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to replace his aging fishing tools. This is the first time that he has requested a loan.

loans.use: To replace his aging fishing tools.

loans.name: Stella's Group

texts.en:
Stella K. has been selling maandazi and fruit in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for four years. Maandazi is a small, donut-like square of fried, semi-sweet dough. They are commonly eaten for breakfast and as a snack throughout Tanzania.

Stella works for twelve hours every day and earns a profit of approximately US$ 180 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more ingredients for maandazi and more fruit for her shop. If this loan helps her to expand her business, she intends to use the increased profit to pay her child's school fees and improve her home.

Stella is 40 years old, married, and has one 22-year-old child. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Erde and Maryam. Each has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for maandazi

loans.name: Mkianaisha's Group

texts.en:
Mkianaisha M. sells chapati and other small food items in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar. Chapati is a flat pancake that is fried in oil and usually cooked over coals. It is served for breakfast, lunch, or as a snack during the day, and it can be eaten plain or rolled up with a fruit or vegetables inside. Mkianaisha works from 6:00am to 10:00pm every day and earns a profit of approximately $20 each month. She has previously taken out one loan from BRAC Tanzania which she repaid successfully and on time. She is requesting her second loan so that she can buy more ingredients for the food and increase her sales and profit.

Mkianaisha is 29 years old, divorced, and has one 5-year-old child. She also cares for two additional dependents. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Zuhura, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for chapati.

loans.name: Amada

texts.es:
La Sra. Amada tiene 72 años de edad, con dos hijos que ya son mayores de edad, todos están casados y viven con sus respectivas familias. Vive en su casa, la cual está ubicada al costado del cementerio municipal. En dicho domicilio tiene su despensa muy bien montada, está en una zona muy bien ubicada donde posee muy buena clientela, ya que no tiene competencia por la zona.

Amada antes de iniciar su negocio se dedicaba a la costura de prendas de vestir (pantalón, camisa, etc.), actividad que hasta hoy día realiza pero en sus tiempos libres. La despensa que posee se encuentra activa hace 18 años, y gracias al ingreso que obtuvo con las ventas en tal negocio pudo comprar su hogar propio y todas las comodidades que posee en la actualidad.

En esta oportunidad solicita el crédito para la compra de más mercaderías tales como: arroz, harina, azúcar, fideo, etc. con el fin de surtir un poco más su negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Amada is 72, with 2 grown children, both married and living with their respective families. She lives in her house located beside the municipal cemetery. This home has a well-set-up shop in a good location with a very good clientele, because she does not have competition in the area. Before starting her business, Amada sewed garments (pants, shirts, etc.), an activity that she continues up to the present in her free time. Her shop has been active for 18 years, and thanks to the sales income she was able to buy her own home as well as all the conveniences she currently possesses. She is taking this opportunity to request credit to buy more merchandise such as rice, wheat, sugar, noodles, etc. with the goal of further supplying her business.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice, wheat, sugar, noodles, breads, etc.

loans.name: Antonio

texts.es:
Antonio S. tiene 46 años de edad, vive en pareja con Severiana de 41 años. Antonio, por cosas de la vida no pudo tener hijos, fue por eso que decidieron junto con su compañera, adoptar una niña que hoy ya tiene 6 años de edad.

Comenta que provenía de una familia muy humilde y por tal motivo no pudo terminar sus estudios en la primaria.

Antonio desde muy pequeño se dedicó a trabajar en la olería de su padre, tal es así que continua hasta hoy día con dicha actividad, la cual es la elaboración y venta de ladrillos.

Actualmente es él quien maneja todo el negocio y ya cuenta con una clientela muy bien formada, principalmente los propietarios de depósitos de ventas de materiales de construcción.

Gracias a su esfuerzo y dedicación ha logrado salir adelante y consiguió progreso tanto para él como para toda su familia.

En esta oportunidad necesita de un crédito para la compra de una buena cantidad de leña para almacenar, ya que utiliza la misma para la cocción de sus productos.
texts.en:
Antonio S. , 46, lives with Severiana, 41. Antonio, who because of life circumstances was unable to have children, decided with his companion to adopt a daughter who is now 6 years old. He comments that he came from a very humble family and therefore was not able to complete his primary education. Antonio recently began to work in his father's brick works, continuing up to the present in the activity of preparing and selling bricks. It is he who actually manages the whole business, and he already has a loyal clientele, mainly proprietors of construction supplies warehouses. Thanks to his effort and dedication, he has succeeded in getting ahead and making progress as much for himself as for his whole family. At this time he needs a loan to purchase a good quantity of firewood to store up, which he uses to fire his products.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of firewood

loans.name: Sowra A 2002-1 Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rose A.. She is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Rose is 40 years old and is married with a husband who is a polceman. She has 5 children ranging from age 9 to 21 and her children go to school. Each week, Rose makes approximately 100 Sudanese pounds in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

Rose is joined in her small group by Esther M., Lucia A. , Seidia C., and Siama S.. Esther M. has a business in selling bread and wants to expand her business. Lucia A. is currently operating a business selling bread and charcoal and wants a loan to open a bar. Seidia C. operates a business of selling selling cold drinks like soda, juice, etc. and wants to expand the business. Siama S. is currently in the business of selling bread and tea at a resturant and is requesting a loan to expand the business.

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: Mwasiku's Group

texts.en:
Mwasiku O. has owned a beauty salon in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for two years. She works from 8:00am to 10:00pm every day and earns a profit of approximately $160 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her salon to increase her sales and profit.

Mwasiku is 45 years old, married, and has two children, aged 9 and 10. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Mwanahamis, who has her own small business selling chicken and charcoal in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more items necessary for her salon.

loans.name: Aziza's Group

texts.en:
Aziza K. has been selling chipsi in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for four years. Chipsi are what Americans call "french fries". They are a common snack in Tanzania. Aziza works fro 8:00am to 8:00pm every day and earns a profit of approximately $240 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more ingredients and increase her sales and profit.

Aziza is 46 years old, married, and has two children, aged 25 and 27. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Mtumwa, who has her own small business selling chipsi and cassava in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to make chipsi to sell.

loans.name: Gilberto

texts.es:
Gilberto tiene 39 años de edad, vive en pareja hace 13 años con Mariza y juntos han criado a dos niños que hoy tienen 2 y 6 años respectivamente.

Comienza diciendo que cuando niño realizaba trabajos en la chacra de su padre. Una vez llegado a la adolescencia, como tantos otros paraguayos, tuvo que partir al país vecino de la Argentina con el fin de hacerse de una profesión con el cual poder vivir dignamente. Fue así que trabajó por muchos años como constructor y en ese tiempo conoció a la que sería su compañera de toda la vida.

Volvió después de 15 años a su ciudad natal, Itá, donde compró una camioneta y montó su pequeña despensa. En la misma, además de vender los productos necesarios para la canasta familiar, también tiene una mesa de billar que constituye la diversión de todos los jóvenes del barrio.

Con su camioneta realiza fletes hasta distintos puntos de la ciudad.

En esta oportunidad solicita el crédito para surtir mejor su negocio con mercaderías tales como: harina, arroz, azúcar, fideos, etc.
texts.en:
Gilberto is 39 years old and lives with his partner of 13 years with whom he has two children who today are 2 and 6 years old, respectively.

He begins by telling us that, when he was a child, he worked on his father’s farm. Once he reached adolescence, like many other Paraguayans, he had to leave his country and travel to Argentina with the goal of finding a profession which would allow him to live with dignity. In this manner, he worked for many years in construction, during which time he met his companion for life.

After fifteen years he returned to Itá, his native city, where he bought his own truck and started his own store. In the store, in addition to selling basic necessities, he also has a billiards table which provides a diversion for the youngsters of the neighborhood. With his truck, he provides charters to different areas of the city.

In this opportunity, he requests the loan to better supply his business with merchandise such as: flour, rice, sugar, noodles, etc.


Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sugar, flour, rice, noodles, and beverages.

loans.name: Somaya

texts.en: Somaya is a 49 year old woman. She lives in a small village near Saida in southern Lebanon. She owns a small sewing shop.  She makes “Lebanese abaya” which is a typical Lebanese kind of dress. She also makes bed covers , and hair covers, or “hijab”. She wants a loan of 1000 US dollars in order to buy raw materials like thread, fabric etc. Somaya has been a micro-credit client for 2 years and has always paid on time.

loans.use: To buy new materials

loans.name: Salomat

texts.ru: Касимова Саломат, 1962 года рождения, замужем и у них 5 детей. Начала свой бизнес с продажи зелени и овощей. Данный момент она торгует овощами и фруктами на колхозном рынке города Турсунзаде. В ее ассортименте разновидность яблок, виноградов, персиков, перца и баклажана, помидоров и огурцов. Также в сезон в продаже имеются дыни, гранаты, хурмы, малины, клубники и т.д. Закупает свои товары с дехкан и у оптовиков из Узбекистана. Для увеличения ассортимента, закупа винограда и яблок  хочет участвовать в программе «Кива» и получить займ в сумме 3500 сомони для увеличения ассортимента.
texts.en:
Salomat K. was born in 1962, is married and has five children. She began her business by selling greens and vegetables. Currently, she sells vegetables and fruit in the farmers’ market in the city of Tursun-Zade. Her inventory includes various types of apples, grapes, peaches, peppers, eggplants, tomatoes and cucumbers. Also during the growing season, she sells melons, pomegranates, persimmons, raspberries, strawberries, etc. She buys the goods from small farmers and from wholesalers from Uzbekistan. She wants to participate in Kiva to receive a loan for 3,500 somoni which will allow her to buy grapes and apples in order to increase her inventory.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grapes and apples

loans.name: Mosi's Group

texts.en:
Mosi Shaaban has owned a restaurant in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She works for 12 hours every day and earns a profit of approximately $155 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food for her restaurant. If this loan helps her expand and improve her business, she intends to use the increased profits to pay for her children's school fees and improve her home.

Mosi is 45 years old, married, and has seven children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Haiba, who has a small business selling vegetables in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more food for her restaurant

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
La señora Lucía, de 40 años de edad, domiciliada en el Barrio Cerro Corá de la Ciudad de Itá, está casada con el Señor César con quien tiene dos hijos, de 19 y 10 años de edad. De profesión artesana en tejido, dejó de ejercer tal profesión a causa del viaje de su hermana a España y ya no pudo comercializar sus productos lo cual hacía a través de la misma, quedando solo el ingreso del marido, quien es empleado del Frigorífico Frigomer para el sustento de la familia.

La situación era cada vez más insostenible ya que el hijo mayor ingresó en la carrera de Arquitectura de la Universidad Nacional de Asunción, aumentando de esta manera cada vez más los gastos.

Fue así que decidió montar otro negocio, hoy día cuenta con una despensa donde la misma trabaja con el objetivo de mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia. Ha decidido confiar en la Fundación Paraguaya para ampliar su negocio y de esta manera acrecentar el ingreso económico posibilitando a los hijos seguir con sus estudios.

Toda la familia se encuentra agradecida con la Fundación por brindarles la oportunidad de trabajar gracias a la aprobación del crédito solicitado.

El crédito que solicita lo invertirá en arroz, harina, azúcar, fideo, etc. con el fin de surtir un poco más su negocio.
texts.en:
Ms. Lucia, age 40, lives in the Cerro Corá neighborhood in the city of Itá. She is married to Mr. César, with whom she has 2 children, ages 19 and 10. She used to knit traditional clothing, but she stopped doing so because her sister went to Spain and as a result, she was no longer able to sell her handmade products because her sister was the one who helped her with that. She was left only with her husband’s income; he works for the Frigorífico Frigomer Company in order to support the family.

Their situation grew more and more unsustainable because the eldest son began studying architecture in the Universidad Nacional de Asunción (National University of Asunción), which further increased their expenses.

This was how she decided to start another business. Today she runs a general store with the aim of improving her family’s living conditions. She has decided to trust in Fundación Paraguaya in order to expand her business, and as a consequence, increase her income so that her children can continue with their studies.

The entire family expresses gratitude for the Fundación for giving them the opportunity to work thanks to the loan approval.

The loan being requested will be invested in rice, flour, sugar, noodles, etc. so that she can increase her merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase flour, sugar, rice, noodles, bread, etc.

loans.name: Salim

texts.en: Salim is a 31 year old man. She lives in a small village near Saida in southern Lebanon. He is a farmer who plants bananas. He has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua to purchase fertilizers and pesticides. This is the first time that he has requested a loan.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides.

loans.name: Nadine

texts.en: Nadine is a 26 year-old woman who lives in a small village near Saida city. She is a hair dresser and a make-up specialist. Nadine wishes to purchase accessories for her salon, such as a hair dryer, mirrors, hair brushes and other essential materials. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua. This is the first time that she has requested a loan.

loans.use: To purchase accessoriees for her salon.

loans.name: Lucila

texts.es:
Lucila tiene 40 años, es madre soltera de dos hijos de 8 y 18 años de edad, vive en la casa de su madre situada al costado del mercado municipal.

Proviene de una familia muy humilde, por tal motivo solo pudo terminar la primaria.

Lucila posee un comedor dentro del mercado municipal en donde tiene venta de comidas típicas como ser: empanadas de mandioca y de harina, butifarra (comida típica paraguaya), asadito carne y chanco, etc. El negocio ya cuenta con 15 años de antigüedad y le da la posibilidad de costear los estudios primarios y universitarios de sus dos hijos.

Recuerda que sus inicios como comerciante fueron muy duros y que con mucho esfuerzo pudo hacerse de capital para montar su propio negocio.

Hoy día cuenta con una clientela muy bien formada a pesar de la competencia que existe en dicho lugar. Mucha gente asiste a su local para disfrutar de las delicias que ella cocina y el mismo se llena generalmente los fines de semanas.

Desea adquirir una computadora para sus hijos, y es por ese motivo que recurre a la Fundación Paraguaya, a fin de hacerse acreedora de un préstamo que le dará la posibilidad de adquirir dicha máquina para ayudar a sus hijos con el estudio y también llevar un mejor control de su stock de mercaderías y ventas.
texts.en:
Lucila, 40, is the single mother of two children ages 8 and 18. She lives in her mother's house located next to the municipal market. She comes from a very humble family, and was only able to complete her primary education. Lucila has a lunch counter inside the municipal market, where she sells typical meals such as tapioca and flour pies, butifarra (a typical Paraguayan food), grilled meats, etc. The business, already 15 years old, gives her the opportunity to pay for the primary and university education of her two children. She recalls that initially business was very hard, and that it took great effort to raise the capital to start her own business. Now she has a loyal clientele in spite of the competition in her location. Many people come to her shop to enjoy the delights that she creates, and it usually fills up on the weekends also. She wants to buy a computer for her children, which is why she has come to Foundation Paraguay. She desires a loan that will allow her to acquire the computer to help her children with their studies, and also to keep better control of her inventory and sales.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a computer

loans.name: Judumishe Group

texts.en:
Rehema has been selling chapati and maandazi in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for one year. Chapati is a flat pancake fried in oil and cooked over coals. It is eaten for breakfast, lunch, or as a snack and can be eaten plain or rolled with fruits or vegetables inside. Maandazi are a small, donut-like square of fried semi-sweet dough. Both chapati and maandazi are common foods in Tanzania.

Rehema earns a profit of approximately $80 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more vegetable oil and flour for the foods that she prepares. If this loan helps her to expand her business, she intends to use the increased profits to get more food for her family and improve her home.

Rehema is 21 years old, married, and has no children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Fatma, who has her own small business selling clothes in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more vegetable oil, flour, and other ingredients for the foods she prepares.

loans.name: Milciades

texts.es:
El Sr. Milciades Giménez está casado hace 7 años con Mabel con quien tiene un hijo de 7 años por quien trabaja todos los días para brindarle una buena educación.

Comenta que sus padres se separaron cuando era un niño lo que le obligó a buscar trabajo desde muy joven para poder solventar sus estudios y ayudar a su madre también con los gastos del hogar.

Trabajó como chofer de ómnibus por muchos años y renunció para comprarse un vehiculo que hoy día utiliza como taxi, dicha actividad viene desarrollando hace 1 año con muy buenos resultados.

Cuenta con el apoyo incondicional de su esposa debido a que trabaja a la par de él vendiendo ropas casa por casa, ayudando así a obtener los ingresos necesarios para el sustento familiar.

Solicita un préstamo para la compra de una parada de taxi, ya que en Paraguay, existen varios proveedores de este servicio que están ubicados en esquinas de distintos puntos, y Milciades en la actualidad está alquilando una y eso le genera un costo adicional.
texts.en:
Mr. Milciades Giménez has been married to Mabel for 7 years. They have a seven-year-old son, for whom they work every day so that they can offer him a good education.

His parents separated when he was a child. Because of this, he was obligated to work from a very young age to pay for school and also to help his mother with the household expenses.

He worked as a bus driver for many years and gave it up to buy a vehicle that he now uses as a taxi. He has been pursuing this activity for a year with very good results.

He counts on the unconditional support of his wife, because she sells clothes door to door. In this way, she helps to earn the income necessary for the family’s sustenance.

He is requesting this loan so that he can buy a taxi stand. In Paraguay there are many providers of this service that are located on corners at different points, and Milciades, at present, is renting one, which costs him more.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a taxi stand

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma M. has been selling clothes in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She works from 8:00am to 6:00pm every day and earns a profit of approximately $85 each month. She has previously taken out one loan from BRAC Tanzania which she repaid successfully and on time. She is requesting her second loan so that she can buy more inventory for her shop and increase her sales and profit.

Fatma is 47 years old, married, and has six children, twins aged 10, and other children aged 11, 13, 14, and 20.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rose S.. She is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to build a house to rent out. Rose is 50 years old and is married to a husband who is a teacher. She has 2 children and her children go to school.

Each week, Rose makes approximately 100 Sudanese pounds in profit and with the extra profit from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent out.

Rose is joined in her small group by Jenifa T., Lilian M., Margret K., and Janifa Y.. Jenifa T. has a business selling charcoal and wants to expand her business. Lilian M. is currently operating a business selling green vegetables at the market and wants a loan to expand her business. Margret K. operates a business selling bread and wants to expand the business. Janifa Y. is currently in the business of selling bread and tea at her little restaurant and is requesting a loan to expand the business.

loans.use: to build a house for rent

loans.name: María Elena

texts.es:
La señora María Elena , domiciliada en el Barrio Sportivo de la Ciudad de Itá, está casada con el señor Osvaldo, con quien tiene dos hijos: Gustavo con 30 años de edad, que se desempeña como funcionario del Hospital Nacional de Itauguá desde hace 6 años y Oscar de 19 años quien se encuentra cursando el Tercer Año de la Educación Media.

La misma se desempeña como costurera desde los 18 años de edad, dicho oficio aprendió de la madre, pero no contenta decidió estudiar en la Academia Nuestra Señora de la Asunción donde obtuvo a los 20 años de edad el Título de Corte y Confección.

El señor Osvaldo, aquejado de una enfermedad quedó desempleado, entonces María Elena pasó a ser el sostén de la familia ya que el hijo mayor ha formado su propio hogar.

Reconocida por su buen trabajo nunca le ha faltado clientela pero con el correr del tiempo su único elemento de trabajo fue desgastándose, impidiendo esto la entrega puntual de sus confecciones, es por ello que la misma ha puesto su confianza en la Fundación Paraguaya solicitando su apoyo para la adquisición de una máquina de coser nueva y así poder seguir realizando esta labor que con tanto empeño y dedicación lo hace a diario.
texts.en:
Mrs. María Elena, who lives in the district of Sportivo in the city of Itá, is married to Mr. Osvaldo, with whom she has two children. Gustavo is 30 years old and has worked as a civil servant at the National Hospital in Itauguá for 6 years. Oscar is 19 years old and is studying in his third year in secondary school.

María Elena has worked as a seamstress since the age of 18; she learned this craft from her mother. She didn’t have a certificate, so she decided to study in the Academy of Our Lady of Asunción where she earned a dressmaking degree at 20 years of age.

Mr. Osvaldo, was suffering from an illness that left him unemployed, so María Elena started supporting the family since their older son has his own home.

She is recognized for her good work and is never lacking clients. As time passed, though, her unique element of work was wearing out, preventing the timely delivery of her creations. It is because of this that she has put confidence in Fundación Paraguaya, requesting their support for the acquisition of a new sewing machine. This will allow her to continue pursuing this activity that she pursues daily with a lot of determination and dedication.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Abbas

texts.en: Abbas is a 38-year-old man. He lives in small village near Nabatieh with his wife and 4 children. He owns a small shop for selling housewares such as plastic storage containers, utensils, and baking sheets. Abbas wants to purchase a more diverse array of products and has requested a $1000 loan from Al Majmoua for this purpose. This will be Abbas’s first loan with Al Majmoua.

loans.use: Abbas will use the loan to purchase new types of products for his housewares shop

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
For one year, Mwanajuma A. has been selling food and firewood in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar. She works for 12 hours every day and earns a profit of approximately $360 each month. She has previously taken out one loan from BRAC Tanzania which she repaid successfully. She is requesting her second loan so that she can buy more inventory for her shop, like rice, sugar, and firewood. If this loan helps her to expand her business, she intends to use the increased profits to pay her children's school fees and get more food for her family.

Mwanajuma is 36 years old, married, and has three children, aged 1, 3, and 13.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, rice, and other goods

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed is 48 years old and lives in a small village near the Southern Lebanese town of Nabatieh. He and his wife have been raising a full house of three young children. 

To make a living, Mohammed is a car painter. He is now requesting a $1000 loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy materials for his business. The essential items he needs to purchase include sandpaper, rust remover, primer, and paint. This will be Mohammed’s third loan with Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase a new stock of supplies for his car painting business

loans.name: Salim

texts.en: Salim is a 41 year-old man who lives in a small village near Saida in southern Lebanon. He is a carpenter and hopes to purchase additional wood for his business. He also wants to pay the school fees for his children. He is requesting a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to cover his expenses. This is the fourth time that he has requested a loan from Al Majmoua and has always paid on time.

loans.use: To purchase wood and pay his children's school fees.

loans.name: Naaem

texts.en:
Naaem is a 52 year-old man who lives in a small village near the city of Nabatieh with his wife and two children. Naaem operates a mini-market where he sells cooking products and simple foods such as seeds, nuts, and candies. 

Naaem wants to diversify his selection of products in order to better accommodate his clients. He has asked for a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua to do so. This is the second time Naaem will be working with Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase a new stock of simple foods and merchandise for his shop

loans.name: Saumu's Group

texts.en:
Saumu has been selling charcoal in the Darajabovu neighborhood of Zanzibar for two years. She works for twelve hours every day and earns a profit of approximately $40 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy charcoal in a greater quantity than she would otherwise be able to. If this loan helps her to expand her business, she intends to use the increased profits to reinvest in her business so that it can continue to grow.

Saumu is 23 years old, married, and has three children, aged 2, 3, and 6. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Rehema, Asha, Pili, and Maryam. Each has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy charcoal in a larger quantity.

loans.name: Divino Niño Jesus Group

texts.es:
El Grupo denominado Divino Niño Jesús, se conformó en fecha 03 de setiembre de 2008, gracias a promociones hechas por la asesora en la zona, quien comentó con la Sra. Norma E.,(actual Directora General del grupo) del programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras. La misma se mostró muy interesada por dicho programa y logró juntar a 17 mujeres.

Cada una de estas señoras posee una actividad específica, las cuales detallamos a continuación:

1) Norma E.. Venta de comidas.

2) Librada Gómez. Despensa.

3) Francisca A.. Despensa.

4) Liliana M.. Venta de bebidas.

5) Lucia G.. Venta de ropas artesanales.

6) Rosa Samudio. Venta de verduras.

7) Ana D.. Venta de bijouterie y lencerías.

8) Reina S.. Venta de productos de limpieza.

9) Elena González. Venta de bebidas.

10) Aurora C.. Despensa.

11) Nilce Álvarez. Venta de cosméticos.

12) Nilsa Giménez. Venta de comidas.

13) Mónica González. Venta de comidas.

14) Lorenza Rodríguez. Venta de ropas.

15) Nelly W..Venta de sábanas.

16) Cinthya González. Venta de sábanas.

17) Remigia C.. Despensa.

El crédito que retirán será para comprar mercaderías para sus negocios, dependiendo de que tipo de actividad manejan. Compra de ingredientes para la preparación de comidas, compra de mercaderías para la despensa como azúcar, arroz, fideo, panificados, lácteos, carnes, yerba, etc., además cosméticos, compra de bebidas, compra de ropas, compra de bijouterie, compra de lencerías, compra de productos de limpieza, compra de ropas, compra de sábanas, compra de verduras y compra de materiales para la confección de ropas artesanales. Todas las integrantes asisten a las reuniones semanales y realizan actividades para recaudar fondos para el bien común del grupo.
texts.en:
The group called “Divino Niño Jesús” (Divine Baby Jesus) was established on September 3, 2008 thanks to the publicity done by the advisor in the area, who discussed the Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras (Committee of Enterprising Women) with Ms. Norma E., current general director of the group. She showed an interest in this program and managed to bring together 17 women.

Each one of these women owns a particular business, including the following: 1) Norma E.. Food sales.

2) Librada Gómez. General store.

3) Francisca A.. General store.

4) Liliana M.. Beverage sales.

5) Lucia G.. Traditional clothing.

6) Rosa Samudio. Vegetable sales.

7) Ana D.. Lingerie and costume jewelry sales.

8) Reina S.. Cleaning product sales.

9) Elena González. Beverage sales.

10) Aurora C.. General store.

11) Nilce Álvarez. Cosmetic sales.

12) Nilsa Giménez. Food sales.

13) Mónica González. Food sales.

14) Lorenza Rodríguez. Clothing sales.

15) Nelly W.. Bed sheet sales.

16) Cinthya González. Bed sheet sales.

17) Remigia C.. General store.

The loan they are currently requesting will be used to purchase assorted merchandise depending on their businesses. They will purchase the ingredients needed for food preparation, goods such as sugar, rice, noodles, bread, dairy products, meats, herbs, etc., cosmetics, beverages, clothing, costume jewelry, lingerie, cleaning products, bed sheets, vegetables, and materials needed for making tradictional clothing. All of the members attend weekly meetings and put on fundraisers for the good of the group.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase assorted merchandise

loans.name: Shaheed

texts.en:
Shaheed is 38 years old and lives with his wife and four children in a small village near the Southern Lebanese city of Nabatieh. 

Shaheed owns a tractor and is contracted to till the land of local farmers who cannot afford a tractor of their own. Currently, his tractor suffers from many mechanical problems. In order to repair it, he needs additional money. Thus, he has requested a loan of 900 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to repair it.

loans.use: To perform repairs on his tractor

loans.name: Bahati's Group

texts.en:
Bahati S. has been selling firewood and charcoal in the Darajabovu neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She works for twelve hours every day and earns a profit of approximately $30 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more firewood and charcoal for her busienss and increase her sales and profit. If this loan helps her to expand her business, she intends to use the increased profits to get more food for her family and to reinvest in her business so that it can continue to grow.

Bahati is 27 years old, married, and has three children, aged 9 years, 6 years, and 3 months. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Mkasi, Maina, and Khadija. Each has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood at greater quantities.

loans.name: Nazem

texts.en:
Nazem is a 45 year-old man. He lives with his wife and three children in a small village near the city of Nabatieh. 

Nazem is a cab driver, but his taxi is currently in serious disrepair. As a result of the taxi’s frequent break-downs, he is struggling to support his family. 

Nazem has requested a loan of $1000 USD from Al Majmoua in order to cover the costs of repair and maintenance. This is the first time that Nazem has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To repair his broken taxicab

loans.name: Abass

texts.en: Abass is 43 years old and lives in Nabatieh with his wife and 7 children. He works as a carpenter and wants to purchase new and more varied types of wood for his business.  To do so, he has asked Al Majmoua for a loan of 800 US dollars. Abass has been a micro-credit client with Al Majmoua for 2 years and he has always repaid his loans in full and on time.

loans.use: The loan will be used to purchase a stock of wood for Abass' carpentry business

loans.name: Jazmín Group

texts.es:
Comité Jazmín, así se denomina el comité integrado por 16 mujeres del Bº Anahí de la ciudad de Capiatá, este grupo se conformó gracias a que la actual presidenta Valentina A. se acercó a la asesora en una reunión que la misma tenía en la zona para averiguar acerca del Programa del Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, la misma quedó muy entusiasmada y logró conformar su grupo en fecha 12 de setiembre del 2008 con 16 mujeres, quienes se encuentran muy contentas trabajando con este programa.

Las integrantes de este grupo destinan su crédito a diferentes actividades tales como:

1. Valentina A.. Confección y venta de ropas artesanales.

2. Silvina Montiel. Venta de comidas.

3. Raquel A.. Venta de ropas.

4. Rosa A.. Venta de ropas y lencerías.

5. Marina Pérez. Venta de comidas.

6. Evangelista A.. Venta de comidas y bebidas.

7. Celia González. Venta de comidas.

8. Gabriela A.. Venta de comidas.

9. Milda R.. Venta de golosinas.

10. Gladys González. Costurera.

11. Andresa R.. Venta de comidas.

12. Nilva P.. Venta de remedios refrescantes.

13. Ida E.. Venta de lencerías.

14. Ester R.. Venta de frutas y verduras.

15. Amancia Benítez. Venta de comidas.

16. Limpia P.. Venta de comidas.

Todas las integrantes del grupo demuestran compañerismo y solidaridad, asisten a las reuniones semanales y realizan actividades para recaudar fondos para el bien común del grupo.

Invertirán su crédito en compra de materiales para la confección de ropas artesanales, compra de ingredientes para la preparación de comidas, compras de lencerías, compra de ropas, compra de remedios refrescantes, compra de frutas y verduras, compra de golosinas, compra de telas e hilos para la confección de ropas.
texts.en:
Jazmín Committee is made up of 16 women of Bº Anahí from the city of Capiatá. This group was brought together because the current president Valentina A. was approached by a counselor in a meeting about the Program of the Committee of Enterprising Women. Valentina was very enthusiastic and succeeded in making her group on September 12, 2008 with 16 women, who are very happy to be working with this program.

The members of this group will use their loan for different activities including the following:

1. Valentina A.. To make and sell traditional clothes. 2. Silvina Montiel. To sell food. 3. Raquel A.. To sell clothes. 4. Rosa A.. To sell clothes and undergarments. 5. Marina Pérez. To sell food. 6. Evangelista A.. To sell food and drinks. 7. Celia González. To sell food. 8. Gabriela A.. To sell food. 9. Milda R.. To sell sweets. 10. Gladys González. Dressmaking. 11. Andresa R.. To sell food. 12. Nilva P.. To sell refreshing comforts. 13. Ida E.. To sell undergarments. 14. Ester R.. To sell fruits and vegetables. 15. Amancia Benítez. To sell food. 16. Limpia P.. To sell food.

All of the members of the group show companionship and solidarity. They attend weekly meetings and pursue activities to collects funds for the common good of the group.

They will invest their loan to buy material to make traditional clothes, ingredients to make food, undergarments, clothes, refreshing comforts, fruits and vegetables, sweets, and fabric and thread to make clothes.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Pasca Juan Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Paska J.. She is currently in the business of selling sweets at her shop and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Paska is 40 years old and is married to a husband who is a teacher. She has 2 children aged between 20 and 25.

Each week, Paska makes approximately 300 Sudanese pounds in profit and with the extra profit from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

Paska is joined in her small group by Nura P., Sarah J., Locia Emmanuel, and Justina S.. Nura P. has a business selling charcoal and wants to expand her business. Sarah J. is currently operating a business selling bread and charcoal and wants a loan to expand her business. Locia Emmanuel operates a business selling bread and wants to expand the business. Justina S. is currently in the business of selling bread and is requesting a loan to expand the business.

loans.use: expand their small businesses

loans.name: La Victoria Group

texts.es:
El Grupo denominado La Victoria se inició en el año 2.008, entusiastas mujeres forman parte de un excelente grupo, cuentan con una comisión bien conformada, el grupo es integrado por 16 señoras, la mayoría de las integrantes realizan emprendimientos orientados al cultivo de: lechuga, tomate, perejil, acelga, rabanitos, etc. para su posterior venta al mercado, la mayoría de los pobladores de la zona donde ellas viven se dedican a la horticultura.

La clasificación de actividades es como sigue:

1- Zunilda Ygnacia Q. – Venta de verduras.

2- Elena O. Morel – Venta de verduras.

3- Florentina R. Cantero – Venta de ropas.

4- Cinecia Carolina P. – Venta de verduras.

5- Lilian Ramona V. – Venta de verduras.

6- Silvina Benítez Cantero – Venta de carbón.

7- Antonia C. Benítez - Venta de verduras.

8- Carol Marlene V. – Venta de verduras.

9- Josefina C. Núñez – Venta de verduras.

10- Alba Rosa M. – Venta de mercería.

11- Ramona V. – Venta de verduras.

12- Paulina Martínez – Venta de verduras.

13- Catalina M. – Venta de comidas.

14- Estefana A. Recalde – Venta de verduras.

15- María Selva Martínez – Venta de cosméticos.

16- Facunda M. de Espínola – Venta de verduras.

Se destaca la solidaridad y la unión que las mismas están forjando entre ellas, asisten voluntariamente a las reuniones, realizan sus pagos en forma puntual.

La comisión nos comentó que optaron por realizar una feria con el objetivo de incentivarlas a mostrar sus productos y para promover la inclusión social.

Consideran la importancia del programa ya que les permite ayudarse y ayudar a gente conocida y de confianza, generando una cadena de colaboración mutua.

Con el crédito desean adquirir insumos para el cultivo de verduras, compra de mercería, compra de ingredientes para la preparación de comidas como: empanadas, pizza, sopa paraguaya, chipa paraguaya para su posterior venta, compra de cosméticos.
texts.en:
The group called La Victoria (The Victory) began in 2008. The enthusiastic women are part of an excellent group, and they count on a well-formed committee. The group is made up of 16 women. Most of the members pursue enterprises related to the farming of: lettuce, tomatoes, parsley, beets, wild radishes, etc. to sell in the market. Most of the women in their area work in agriculture.

The classification of activities is as follows:

1. Zunilda Ygnacia Q. – Sells vegetables. 2. Elena O. Morel – Sells vegetables. 3. Florentina R. Cantero – Sells clothes. 4. Cinecia Carolina P. – Sells vegetables. 5. Lilian Ramona V. – Sells vegetables. 6. Silvina Benítez Cantero – Sells coal. 7. Antonia C. Benítez – Sells vegetables. 8. Carol Marlene V. – Sells vegetables. 9. Josefina C. Núñez – Sells vegetables. 10. Alba Rosa M. – Haberdashery 11. Ramona V. – Sells vegetables. 12. Paulina Martínez – Sells vegetables. 13. Catalina M. – Sells food. 14. Estefana A. Recalde – Sells vegetables. 15. María Selva Martínez – Sells cosmetics. 16. Facunda M. de Espínola – Sells vegetables.

The solidarity and the union that they are forging among them are emphasized. They voluntarily attend meetings and make their payments punctually.

The committee chooses to make a fair with the goal of encouraging the members to show their products and to promote social inclusion.

They consider the program to be important since it allows them to help themselves and to help people they know, generating a chain of mutual collaboration.

With this loan, they want to acquire supplies to farm vegetables, to buy merchandise, to buy ingredients for the preparation of food like: empanadas, pizza, sopa paraguaya, and chipa paraguaya, and to buy cosmetics. These items will later be sold.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy varied merchandise

loans.name: Shindana's Group

texts.en:
Shandana has been selling firewood and kerosene in the Darajabovu neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She works for 12 hours everyday and earns a profit of approximately $70 each month. Having previously taken out a loan from BRAC Tanzania which she repaid on time, Shandana is requesting her second loan in order to open a new business as a tailor to have in addition to her fuel business.

Shandana, 40 years old and married with two children, aged 12 and 20, will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Mwanashawa and Semem. Each has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To open a tailoring business.

loans.name: Amina's Group

texts.en:
Amina M. has been selling mattresses in the Darajabovu neighborhood of Zanzibar for four years. She works for twelve hours every day and earns a profit of approximately $95 each month. She has previously taken out one loan from BRAC Tanzania which she repaid successfully and on time. She is requesting her second loan so that she can buy more mattresses for her business and increase her sales and profit. If this loan helps her to expand her business, she intends to use the increased profits to reinvest in her business so that it can continue to grow.

Amina is 34 years old, married, and has four children, aged 2, 5, 8, and 12. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Halima, who has her own small business selling charcoal and firewood in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more mattresses for her shop.

loans.name: Roland

texts.es: Ronald tiene 36 años, vive con su madre y su hija de 6 años.  Es maestro, pero mas allá de ejercer su profesión, se ha proyectado en tener sus propios ingresos, es así que hace 8 años abrió una tienda, la que instaló en su propia casa, ofrece productos de pan llevar. Cada día se levanta muy temprano para atender su establecimiento y cada 2 semanas, se va temprano para comprar mercadería, de acuerdo a la cantidad de productos que tiene, es así que todas las mañanas está en su tienda y por las por las tardes el se va a enseñar, en su labor de maestro, para  Ronald es una gran satisfacción estar al lado de su familia y sobre todo de su pequeña de 6 años. El motivo del esfuerzo diario de este padres es su pequeña hija. El préstamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de mercadería, con el objetivo de aumentar su capital de trabajo.
texts.en:
Ronald, 36, lives with his mother and his 6-year-old daughter. He is a schoolteacher, and besides practicing his profession, he has also made a way to have his own income. Thus, 8 years ago he opened a shop in his own house, offering take-out bread products. Each day he rises very early to take care of the shop, and every 2 weeks he goes very early to replenish his merchandise according to what is on hand. Thus, every morning, he is in his shop, and in the afternoon he goes to teach. It is a great satisfaction to Ronald to be alongside his family, especially his little 6-year-old. This father's daily motivation is his daughter. He will invest the loan he is requesting in merchandise, with the objective of increasing his working capital.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Additional merchandise for his shop

loans.name: Yayo's Group

texts.en:
Yayo B. has been selling charcoal and firewood in the Darajabovu neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She works for 12 hours every day and earns a profit of approximately $35 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal for her business and so that she can open a small cosmetics shop. If this loan helps her to expand her business, she intends to use the increased profits to reinvest in her business so that it can continue to grow.

Yayo is 34 years old, married, and has 8 children, aged 4, 9, 12, 14, 15, 16, 18, and 19. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Siti, Asia, Zainab, Maryam, and Zena. Each woman has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and open a cosmetics shop

loans.name: Sulma

texts.es: Sulma tiene 50 años, vive  con sus hijos. Es una excelente vendedora, su facilidad de palabra y capacidad de convencer, logra que pueda transar un buen acuerdo de venta de ganado, es así que desde hace 4 años  trabaja en la venta de ganado, compra toretes enflaquecidos y después de 4 meses de hacerlos engordar los vende a un buen precio, de esta manera, sola, mantiene a sus 6 hijos que viven con ella, ellos también le ayudan después de ir a la escuela a cuidar de sus animales, con el pasar del tiempo el capital de trabajo de Sulma se ha ido incrementando, eso la mantiene tranquila y satisfecha, aunque duro, muchas veces por el cuidado minucioso que tiene en la alimentación e higiene de sus animales, es compensador. Sulma se esfuerza para poder cubrir las necesidades de sus hijos, invierte en la alimentación y educación de ellos. En esta ocasión desea que le presten para comprar reses y carneros para con ellos, obtener más ganancias.
texts.en:
Sulma is 50 years old and lives with her children. She is an excellent saleswoman and with her facility for words and capacity to convince she manages to negotiate good deals in cattles sales. For the past 4 years she has worked in the sale of cattle, buying thin calves and after 4 months of fattening them she sells them at a good price. Through this, she alone supports her 6 children who live with her.. They also help to take care of the animals after school. With time Sulma's working capital has increased and this keeps her calm and satisfied and, although it is hard, the care that she has for the feeding and health of her animals is compensatory. Sulma works hard to be able to pay for her children's needs as well as invest in their nutrition and education.In this occasion she wishes that you lend to her to buy cows in order to obtain more earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cattle to increase her earnings.

loans.name: Delfina

texts.es: Delfina tiene 40 años, vive con su esposo e hijos. Se levanta cada día, muy temprano, para recoger el pasto que ha de dar a sus cuyes y sus vacas, esta labor, en las tareas de la agricultura y ganadería la viene haciendo desde hace 17 años, después de que  Delfina se casó y formo una familia, hasta ahora, que junto a su esposo tiene la responsabilidad de educar a sus 3 hijos.  A parte de dar de comer a sus vacas, también vende la leche que producen, y si la cría de su vaca es un toro, lo hace engordar y luego lo vende, en ocasiones también compra toretes y después de unos meses de engorde los vende en las ferias ganaderas. Delfina trabaja en esta actividad porque disfruta de tener la disposición de leche fresca, no solo para vender, sino también para su familia, así como de otros productos, sin necesidad de ir al mercado a comprarlos, es por ello que no solo se ha trazado la meta de tener la misma raza de vacas, sino también en mejorar su calidad a fin de que pueda tener mayores ingresos. Solicita este préstamo con el que podrá comprar algunos cuyes sementales para su granja, así también como la preparación de sus tierras de cultivo, con la compra de abono y fertilizantes para que siembre papa y alfalfa.
texts.en:
Delfina, 40, lives with her husband and children. She rises very early every day to collect the feed to give to her guinea pigs and cows. She has been working in agriculture and livestock breeding for 17 years, from the time Delfina married and formed her family up to her present responsibility, with her husband, of educating her 3 children. Besides feeding her cows, she also sells the milk they produce, and if a bull is produced, she fattens it and then sells it. At times she also buys young bulls and after several months of fattening she sells them at livestock markets. Delfina works at this activity because she enjoys having fresh milk at her disposal, not only to sell, but also for her family, as well as other products, without having to go to the market to buy them. This is why she not only has set herself the goal to maintain the lineage of her cattle, but also to improve their quality in order to increase her income. She is requesting this loan so she can purchase some breeder guinea pigs for her farm, as well as improvements to her agricultural land with manure and fertilizers to grow potatoes and alfalfa.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of breeder guinea pigs, plus improvement of her agricultural land to grow potatoes and alfalfa

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: Maria tiene 39 años, vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos. Junto a su esposo, desde hace15 años, viene dedicándose arduamente, en lo que es para ellos un esfuerzo familiar, su propia fábrica de ladrillos, en un inicio, solo ellos trabajaban todo el día en fabricación de los ladrillos, desde obtener la materia prima, mezclar los materiales, amasar y moldear la mezcla, caldear el horno, para luego hacerlos cocer cerca de 3 días, ahora, con el crecimiento gradual de su negocio familiar, tienen la posibilidad de contratar peones para esta labor, aunque de todas maneras Maria y su esposo siguen dedicándose a esta labor, debido al aumento de pedidos de ladrillos, que son vendidos por millares y en las ferias de construcción.  Maria trabaja de esta manera para sustentar la economía de su hogar y los gastos de estudios de sus hijos. Solicita este préstamo con el que podrá comprar leña para su horno de ladrillos y también para el pago de jornal de los peones que contratará.
texts.en:
Maria, 39, lives with her husband and 3 children. Fifteen years ago, with their usual dedication, they began their own brick manufacture. In the beginning, they worked all alone making the bricks, gathering the materials, mixing, molding the mixture, heating the kiln, and finally baking the bricks for 3 days. Now, with the gradual growth of their family business, they have the opportunity to hire laborers for this work, although in any case Maria and her husband will continue giving themselves to their business, thanks to the increasing orders for bricks, that are sold by the thousands and in construction markets. Maria works like this to support the expenses of the household and her children's education. She is requesting this loan so she can purchase firewood for her brick kiln and also to pay her day laborers.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of firewood for her brick kiln.

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es: Isabel tiene 39 años, vive con su madre y con su hijo. Desde hace 3 años decidió tener su granja de cuyes, con la finalidad de venderlos y obtener las ganancias que requiere, su madre fue quien dio la iniciativa, con el paso del tiempo, se dio cuenta de esta era una buena opción de desarrollo para ella y su familia. Cada día va a recoger el pasto de sus tierras para dárselo a sus cuyes, siempre está al pendiente del crecimiento y de las nuevas crías, para lo cual hace un cuidadoso y estricto control, luego los vende de acuerdo a su peso, el crecimiento de su granja se dio por la constante dedicación de Isabel, tiene cerca de 360 cuyes, esto le genera buenas ganancias, es por ello que sigue dedicándose al cuidado de su granja de cuyes.  La mayor motivación para Isabel es su hijo, ella desea a poyarlo hasta que sea profesional. Solicita este préstamo para la compra de corrales de madera, ya que en su granja está aumentando la población de cuyes. En el futuro, quiere ser una granjera de éxito.
texts.en:
Isabel, 39, lives with her mother and her son. Three years ago she decided to undertake a guinea pig farm, with the goal of selling them for the income she needs. Her mother gave her the impetus, and over time, she has realized that this is an excellent means of development for herself and her family. She goes out every day to gather grass from her lands to feed her guinea pigs. She is always on the lookout for growth and for new litters, keeping careful and strict control, then she sells them by weight. The growth of her farm is the result of Isabel's constant dedication, now up to about 360 guinea pigs, generating a good income. This is why she continues to make her living from her guinea pig farm. Isabel's first motivation is her son, whom she would like to support until he becomes a professional. She is requesting this loan to purchase wooden pens for the increasing stock of guinea pigs. In the future, she hopes to be a successful farmer.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wooden pens for her guinea pigs

loans.name: Time's Group

texts.en:
Time J. has been selling maandazi in the Darajabovu neighborhood of Zanzibar for two years. Maandazi is a small, square, fried food of semi-sweet dough, similar to a donut. She works for six hours every day and earns a profit of approximately $25 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more ingredients for maandazi, like flour, sugar, and oil. If this loan helps her to expand her business, she intends to use the increased profits to reinvest in her business so that it can continue to grow.

Time is 28 years old, married, and has two children, aged 2 and 11. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Aisha, Sauda, Mkasi, Mpoti, and Mwawuma. Each woman has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for her maandazi business.

loans.name: Andrea

texts.es: Andrea tiene 22 años, vive con su esposo. Desde hace un año tiene una granja de cuyes, no descuida la limpieza, ni la alimentación de sus animalitos, periódicamente los hace revisar con un veterinario, esta labor la realiza todos los días, con la finalidad de obtener la ventas  deseadas, es por ello que espera con gran paciencia los días miércoles de cada semana para venderlos en una feria comercial cercana a su localidad, así mismo tiene clientes que compran sus cuyes cada cierto tiempo, por lo que se siente satisfecha de la labor que realiza cada día. El motivo de su esfuerzo es formar un hogar sólido para los hijos que ella ha de tener.  Solicita este préstamo para la compra de más cuyes reproductores y para sembrar más alfalfa.
texts.en:
Andrea is 22 years old and lives with her husband. For the past year, she has had her own guinea pig farm (guinea pig is considered a delicacy in Peru). She takes care to keep her little animals clean and well-fed, and periodically takes them to the veterinarian for checkups. She works on her farm every day with the aim of reaching her sales goals. Each week, she waits patiently for Wednesday to come around, since that is the day she sells the animals in a nearby commercial market. She also has regular customers who buy guinea pigs from her every so often. She feels satisfied with the work she does each day, and works with the aim of building a strong home for the children she plans to have someday. She is requesting this loan to buy more guinea pigs to breed as well as to buy more seeds to plant alfafa, which she will use to feed the animals.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy guinea pigs to breed and plant more alfafa for them to eat

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: Mohammed is 31 years old and lives with his wife and one child in a small village called Rashaia, in Lebanon’s Bekaa Valley. Mohammed is a car electrician and has asked Al Majmoua for a loan of 1000 US Dollars in order to purchase a supply of car batteries. This will be Mohammed’s first loan with Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase new car batteries for his auto repair business

loans.name: Sofia

texts.es: Sofía tiene 35 años, vive con sus hijos. Ella tiene un talento especial para elaborar bellos trabajos de bordados de  fustanes folklóricos de su zona, desde niña lo viene haciendo, su trabajo consiste en diseñar previamente el motivo o imagen, para luego realizar los bordados, tendiendo sumo cuidado en la combinación de colores que usará, es por ello que es muy importante la calidad de hilos que utiliza para poder tener un acabado de calidad, se dedica a esta labor casi todo el día, además de la crianza de animales de corral, sin descuidar el cuidado de sus 3 hijos que están estudiando. Sofía trabaja motivada por ser un sostén para su hogar.  Solicita un préstamo para la compra de hilos y telas para sus bordados, además, para la compra de lana, porque también se dedica al tejido de chompas a palito.
texts.en:
Sofía, 35, lives with her children. She has a special talent creating beautiful embroidery on local folk skirts, which she has been doing since she was a girl. Her work includes first designing the image or motif, then creating the embroidery, using extreme care in the combination of colors she will use. For her, the quality of thread she uses is very important in order to have a quality product. She spends almost all day at this work, as well as raising animals in pens, without neglecting the care of her 3 school-age children. Sofía is motivated to work to support her household. She is requesting a loan to buy threads and fabrics for her embroideries, as well as to purchase yarn, because she also weaves patterned sweaters.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of materials for her embroidery.

loans.name: Namagoona Group

texts.en:
Christine N. is the charming 34-year-old leader of the Namagoona Borrowing Group in Nabweru, a suburban village 8 km outside of Kampala. Christine is a single mother supporting her 14-year-old son in boarding school and her deceased sister’s orphans, an 11-year-old girl and a 17-year-old boy. Christine is an articulate and smart businesswoman who sells jewelry and beauty supplies to local salons. Because this is a cyclical business, she augments her income by also raising and selling chickens, and growing maize.

Christine has been a hard-working microfinance borrower for over 3 years. This is her twelfth loan. She will use the proceeds of this loan to invest in each of her businesses, as follows: 600,000 UGX to purchase 300 chicks and feed; 500,000 UGX to replenish her jewelry and beauty inventories; and 900,000 UXG for gardening tools, fertilizers and tools for the corn business.

Microfinance loans from Pearl allow Christine to continually grow her operations and launch new sources of income, such as the recent addition of her maize farm. Compassionate and generous, Christine uses the profits to pay for her children’s school fees, clothing and healthcare costs; support her elderly and ill parents; and reinvest in her enterprises. Christine hopes to one day build a nice house with her accumulated savings. Her greatest hope is seeing her son complete his education.

loans.use: To purchase 300 chicks and feed; to replenish her jewelry and beauty inventories; and to purchase gardening tools, fertilizers and tools for the corn business.

loans.name: Martha

texts.es: Martha tiene 47 años, vive con su madre y con su madre. Cada día se levanta muy temprano para ir al mercado y comprar los ingredientes esenciales para la elaboración de tamales, cerca de las 11 de la mañana, sale con los tamales preparados a vender y también a repartir a su clientela. Vende de manera ambulante en la puerta de los colegios, hasta horas de la tarde, donde regresa nuevamente a lavar todo lo que utilizó, de esta manera obtiene las ganancias diarias, ella es el único sostén de su hijo. Martha  disfruta de este trabajo porque le gusta cocinar, además de que este platillo es muy sencillo de elaborar para ella. Martha trabaja por la educación de su hijo,  quiere verlo como un profesional de éxito. Solicita este préstamo para hacer las compras al por mayor de harina de maíz, aceite, entre otros ingredientes para abastecer los pedidos que le solicitan.
texts.en:
Martha, 47, lives with her mother and grandmother. She rises very early every day to go to the market to purchase the essential ingredients to make tamales. By about 11 am, she goes out to sell the prepared tamales, and also to deliver to her clientele. She makes street sales at school entrances. In the afternoon she returns again to wash everything that she used, and in this way she makes her daily income. She is the sole support of her son. Martha enjoys this work because she loves to cook and this dish is very easy for her to make. Martha works for her son's education, she would like to see him become a successful professional. She is requesting this loan to purchase corn flour, oil, and other ingredients wholesale, to stock up for the orders that come to her.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To acquire the ingredients necessary to make tamales

loans.name: Housni

texts.en:
Housni is a 30 year-old man who lives with his parents in the rurA. village of Rashaia in the Bekaa Valley.
